Description: 1979 Solid Body Electric MARTIN & CO Guitar EM-18 RH w Case CONDITION: NO CRACKS, CHIPS, DINGS, BREAKS, OR REPAIRS. THE CHROME BRIDGE LOOKS FROM THE SIDE LIKES IT IS A LITTLE RAISED, BUT THE KNOBS ON THE STRINGS FIT UNDER THERE SO NOT SURE IF THAT IS THE WAY IT IS MADE. STORED WITH LOOSE STRINGS. GENERAL WEAR TYPICAL FOR AGE. DON'T THINK THE CASE IS ORIGINAL BUT NOT SURE. SEE PHOTOS. PLEASE SEE NOTE BELOW ABOUT OTHER EBAYER COMMENTS. APPROXIMATE MEASUREMENTS: 40 INCHES LONG X 12.5 INCHES WIDE.TUNERS ARE ALSO MARKED "MARTIN."Martin introduced the E series in the late-'70s as an attempt to break into the solidbody electric market. Less than 1500 of these guitars were produced before production ended in 1983. The EM-18 (the most common model in the line) featured two exposed humbuckers, an offset body, and a funky scroll-like headstock shape. Body Style: Offset solidbodyYears of Production: 1979 - 1983 Solid maple body with mahogany center strips in natural finish. HERE'S WHAT ANOTHER EBAYER TOLD ME ABOUT THIS GUITAR: This is actually NOT a Martin EM-18 guitar made in the USA. It was made in Japan and imported by Martin as a "kit" guitar for buyers to complete with hardware and electronics of their own choice. Approximately 300 of these guitars were made. Some of them were actually completed by the Martin factory though. The wood on the body of this guitar is ash, not maple. Only the usa made em-18 guitars have maple bodies. The neck is maple while the usa made ones have mahogany necks. These were well made and nice playing guitars and even more rare than a usa made em-18....but were of Japanese manufacture.
